abstract: Berkley Petroleum Corp will consider takeover bids beside the one received from Hunt Oil Company (S)
snippet: Berkley Petroleum Corp will consider takeover bids beside the one received from Hunt Oil Company (S)
lead_paragraph: The Berkley Petroleum Corporation, the target of an unsolicited takeover offer by the Hunt Oil Company, said yesterday that its board approved a temporary shareholder-rights plan that would give it time to consider competing bids. On Wednesday, Hunt Oil, which is closely held by the Hunt family of Dallas, offered 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($927 million), equivalent to 10 dollars a share ($6.67), for Berkley. Berkley's shareholder-rights plan, which requires regulatory approval, would keep bids open 60 days.

lead_paragraph: The Delta Petroleum Corporation, an oil and natural gas exploration company, said yesterday that it had canceled a $49.5 million agreement to buy stakes in about 680 oil and natural gas wells from the Saga Petroleum Corporation. Instead, Delta will buy a single gas property in New Mexico for $2.1 million in cash and $600,000 in stock.

abstract: Editorial welcomes agreement signed by several oil and mining companies with British and American governments and human rights groups on standards for security; calls pact modest step toward reducing major source of abuses committed by corporations in third world
snippet: Editorial welcomes agreement signed by several oil and mining companies with British and American governments and human rights groups on standards for security; calls pact modest step toward reducing major source of abuses committed by corporation...
lead_paragraph: Oil and mining companies do not have the luxury of relocation. They often find themselves working in poor and violent places where protecting a mine or pipeline is a challenge. Occasionally the security forces hired by American or European corporations have gone too far. In the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya in the mid-1990's, military men hired as guards at Freeport-McMoRan's Grasberg gold and copper mine were accused of killing civilians. The security forces contracted by British Petroleum in Colombia, Shell and Chevron in Nigeria, among other companies, have been accused of similar abuses.

abstract: Op-Ed article by former Pres Jimmy Carter describes amazing uncorrupted wilderness that is Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, and urges Pres Clinton to proclaim coastal plain as national monument before he leaves office; warns that Pres-elect George W Bush and Vice Pres-elect Dick Cheney are oil industry veterans who believe, mistakenly, that drilling would have little impact on precious ecosystem (M)

lead_paragraph: Rosalynn and I always look for opportunities to visit parks and wildlife areas in our travels. But nothing matches the spectacle of wildlife we found on the coastal plain of America's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. To the north lay the Arctic Ocean; to the south, rolling foothills rose toward the glaciated peaks of the Brooks Range. At our feet was a mat of low tundra plant life, bursting with new growth, perched atop the permafrost.

abstract: Editorial predicts that oil will soon figure prominently in delicate relationship between US and China; explains that China will become one of world's top oil importers in few years, pushed by its torrid economic growth; hopes for moderating effect on China's behavior as country takes its place among world's great powers and attempts to integrate its economy into global markets
snippet: Editorial predicts that oil will soon figure prominently in delicate relationship between US and China; explains that China will become one of world's top oil importers in few years, pushed by its torrid economic growth; hopes for moderating effec...
lead_paragraph: Oil has not figured prominently in the delicate relationship between the United States and China. But it soon will. China, the world's most populous nation with 1.3 billion people, will become one of the world's top oil importers in just a few years. This growing reliance on imported oil will further anchor China in the global economy and help shape its ties to the United States. Both nations should be thinking about how to manage this new reality and its strategic repercussions not only in East Asia, but also in places like the Middle East.

abstract: Focus on outlook for oil and natural gas industry; gradual and welcome decline in price of oil, which shot up $37 per barrel in September for 10-year high, could be halted and even reversed by continually rising price of natural gas; latter has quadrupled in last 18 months, through combination of high demand and lagging supplies; federal government predicts residential customers who heat with natural gas will face 50 percent increase in heating bills during current winter (Special section); graph (M)
snippet: Focus on outlook for oil and natural gas industry; gradual and welcome decline in price of oil, which shot up $37 per barrel in September for 10-year high, could be halted and even reversed by continually rising price of natural gas; latter has qu...
lead_paragraph: How much longer will this go on? That seemed to be the question for everyone who felt the pinch of oil prices this year, as the cost of a barrel of crude shot past $30 in late winter. The price hit $37 in September, the highest since the Persian Gulf war a decade ago, and gasoline prices in the Midwest climbed to more than $2.50 a gallon, igniting consumer outrage and government inquiries. But the stubbornly high price has begun to slip, falling to less than $30 a barrel earlier this month, even with winter bearing down and stocks of heating oil in the Northeast still sharply below last year's levels.

lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that investors were responding favorably to its hostile bid for Woodside Petroleum, an Australian oil company. The offer, for 14.8 Australian dollars ($8.07) a share or 6.5 billion dollars ($3.5 billion) for the shares it does not already own, is the first part of a two-stage proposal by Shell to raise its stake in Woodside from 34 percent to 56 percent. Woodside has been campaigning against the bid, which is Shell's second. An earlier bid was rejected by Woodside's non-Shell directors.

abstract: Applications for Westchester County-administered Home Energy Assistance Program are being accepted to help eligible individuals and their families pay their home-heating bills (S)
snippet: Applications for Westchester County-administered Home Energy Assistance Program are being accepted to help eligible individuals and their families pay their home-heating bills (S)
lead_paragraph: Applications for the county-administered Home Energy Assistance Program are being accepted to help eligible individuals and families pay their home-heating bills. Last winter, 11,035 Westchester households were helped by the federal program, receiving almost $1 million in aid. Public assistance recipients and food stamp recipients should contact their Social Services District Office. Others can call Westchester Community Opportunities Program at (914) 592-5600. The elderly, disabled and Social Security recipients should call the Westchester County Office for the Aging at (914) 665-5900. Households not receiving public assistance may be eligible for home-heating assistance if their gross monthly income for a family of four, for example, falls at or below $2,857.

abstract: Getty Petroleum Marketing refuses third buyout offer from United Refining Co and urges shareholders to back a bid by Lukoil Holding, of Russia (S)
snippet: Getty Petroleum Marketing refuses third buyout offer from United Refining Co and urges shareholders to back a bid by Lukoil Holding, of Russia (S)
lead_paragraph: Getty Petroleum Marketing Inc. dismissed a third offer by the United Refining Company yesterday and urged shareholders to back a bid by Lukoil Holding of Russia. Getty also said it would fight a New York lawsuit filed by United to block Lukoil's purchase. Getty, which has 1,300 gasoline stations in 13 Northeast and mid-Atlantic states, agreed last month to be acquired by Lukoil for $5 a share, or about $71 million. United's latest offer was for $6 a share, plus absorption of the $5 million breakup fee Getty would owe Lukoil for backing out of their agreement. United owns 303 Kwik Fill and Red Apple filling stations, mostly in New York and Pennsylvania, and a refinery in Warren, Pa., where it is based. Getty is based in Jericho, N.Y.

Getty owns 1,300 gas stations in 12 states. Getty's agreement with Lukoil becomes final today unless Getty accepts United's bid. United owns a refinery in Warren, Pa. Getty is based in Jericho, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: Nine years after the Persian Gulf war, Saddam Hussein remains a menace to American interests in the Middle East. Seeing Gov. George W. Bush flanked recently at his ranch by two architects of the war effort, Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, was a piquant reminder that Washington has unfinished business in Iraq. One of the first tests awaiting Mr. Bush or Vice President Al Gore will be to devise a policy that keeps Mr. Hussein in check even as other nations like Russia and France press to end Iraq's isolation.

lead_paragraph: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners agreed yesterday to buy two oil products pipelines and 12 storage terminals from the GATX Corporation for $1.15 billion in cash and assumed debt. The transaction includes the 550-mile Calnev pipeline operation, which transported an average of 112,000 barrels of refined products a day last year; and the 195-mile central Florida pipeline, which moved a daily average of 85,000 barrels of refined products. The 12 storage terminals have a capacity of 35.6 million barrels, holding both petroleum products and chemicals.

abstract: Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell may have to delay Caspian Sea oil field development because of technical difficulties (S)
snippet: Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell may have to delay Caspian Sea oil field development because of technical difficulties (S)
lead_paragraph: The Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group may have to delay the development of a Caspian Sea oil field until facilities to separate larger-than-usual amounts of sulfur and natural gas from the oil can be built. The companies, together with BP Amoco, the BG Group, TotalFinaElf, Statoil, Eni Inpex of Japan and the Phillips Petroleum Company, are exploring the Kashagan field off Kazakhstan, which by some estimates is the largest oil deposit found in decades. ''Unless we have a robust solution for gas, we'll not be developing the oil field,'' said Keith Dallard, general manager of the venture. ''Over a half of our expenditure could be for gas and sulfur-related facilities, not just for oil.''

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group offers to pay up to $3.4 billion for 66 percent of Woodside Petroleum it does not already own; is giving investors option to buy back shares in merged entity; would hold 56 percent of combined company, up from current 34.3 percent, if all options are exercised; would transfer assets valued at $3.8 billion into Woodside in exchange for 333.3 million new shares (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell Group offers to pay up to $3.4 billion for 66 percent of Woodside Petroleum it does not already own; is giving investors option to buy back shares in merged entity; would hold 56 percent of combined company, up from current 34.3 ...
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group offered to pay as much as $3.4 billion for control of Woodside Petroleum to increase its presence in the Asia-Pacific region. Shell, a British-Dutch company, offered to pay $7.70 a share for the 66 percent of Woodside it did not already own. Shell is giving investors the option to buy back shares in the merged entity at the same price through the end of June. If all the options were exercised, Shell would hold 56 percent of the combined company, up from its current 34.3 percent. As part of the deal, Shell would transfer assets valued at $3.8 billion into Woodside in exchange for 333.3 million new shares. In June, Woodside rejected a bid offering assets worth $3 billion for 428.9 million new shares. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

abstract: Pipeline to carry oil from Tengiz fields of Kazakhstan across Russia to Novorossisk on Black Sea is finished, giving Russia an edge over an American-backed alternative route through Georgia in a race to control oil shipments from Caspian region (S)
snippet: Pipeline to carry oil from Tengiz fields of Kazakhstan across Russia to Novorossisk on Black Sea is finished, giving Russia an edge over an American-backed alternative route through Georgia in a race to control oil shipments from Caspian region (S...
lead_paragraph: A $2.5 billion pipeline to carry oil from the Tengiz fields of Kazakhstan across Russia to Novorossisk on the Black Sea has been finished, its builders say. Its completion gives Russia an edge over an American-backed alternative route through Georgia in a race to control oil shipments from the Caspian region. The group that built the new pipeline, made up of oil companies and the governments of Russia, Kazakhstan and Oman, said oil would begin flowing through the 560,000-barrel-a-day line in mid-2001. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

snippet: Phillips Petroleum and Anadarko Petroleum begin production at Alpine oil field in Alaska, described as biggest onshore oil discovery in US in a decade; field is expected to produce 80,000 barrels a day by end of year from 16 production wells (S)
lead_paragraph: Phillips Petroleum and Anadarko Petroleum said yesterday that they had started production at the Alpine oil field in Alaska, described as the biggest onshore oil discovery in the United States in a decade. The field is expected to produce 80,000 barrels a day by the end of the year from 16 production wells. Phillips owns 78 percent of the field, Anadarko the remainder. Since it acquired Atlantic Richfield's oil fields in the state earlier this year, Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., has been the biggest oil producer in Alaska.

lead_paragraph: Getty Petroleum Marketing Inc., which on Nov. 2 agreed to be bought by Lukoil Holding of Russia for $5 a share, said yesterday that it was now considering a $5.75-a-share offer from another bidder, the United Refining Company of Warren, Pa. Getty, based in Jericho, N.Y., owns or operates 1,300 gas stations in 12 states. In addition to a refinery in Warren, United operates 303 gas stations in New York and Pennsylvania. If Getty backs out of the Lukoil deal, the first in which a Russian company would acquire a publicly held American one, Getty would be obliged to pay Lukoil $3 million to $5 million in expenses.

abstract: BP Amoco is in talks to invest about $200 million in China National Offshore Oil Corp; stake in China National would give BP Amoco a share in oil production off Chinese coast, where China National has a monopoly (S)
snippet: BP Amoco is in talks to invest about $200 million in China National Offshore Oil Corp; stake in China National would give BP Amoco a share in oil production off Chinese coast, where China National has a monopoly (S)
lead_paragraph: BP Amoco is in talks to invest about $200 million in the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, an official at the Chinese company said. A stake in China National would give BP Amoco a share in oil production off the Chinese coast, where China National now has a monopoly. Most of the increase in China's oil output in the next few years is expected to come from offshore, industry analysts say. BP Amoco, one of the largest foreign investors in China, has spent more than $2.5 billion developing oil fields and building chemical plants there and has invested about $1 billion in shares of the two largest oil companies, the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation and the PetroChina Company. China National is the third largest.

The latest example was Iraq's demand that the United Nations allow it to get euros for its oil exports, not dollars. Iraq threatened to shut off its oil exports otherwise, so the U.N. capitulated. abstract: Stone Energy Co, independent oil and gas company, acquires Basin Exploration in stock swap valued at $380 million and assumption of $48 million of Basin's debt (S)
snippet: Stone Energy Co, independent oil and gas company, acquires Basin Exploration in stock swap valued at $380 million and assumption of $48 million of Basin's debt (S)
lead_paragraph: The Stone Energy Corporation, an independent oil and gas company based in Lafayette, La., agreed to buy Basin Exploration, a competitor, in a stock swap valued at $380 million based on closing prices yesterday. Stone will also assume about $48 million of Basin's debt. Both companies are active in the Gulf of Mexico. The deal will increase Stone's oil reserves by about 54 percent and its daily production by 50 percent. Basin stockholders will receive 0.3974 share of Stone for each share of Basin, and Basin's chief executive, Michael Smith, will join Stone Energy's board, Stone said.

lead_paragraph: Conoco, one of the largest oil companies in the United States, agreed to buy a 6.4 percent interest in a North Sea oil field from Norway's Statoil for about $60 million to bolster its output in the region. The acquisition by the Conoco's Norwegian affiliate, Norske Conoco, in the sea's Grane Field reserve will add more than 13,000 barrels of oil to its daily production. Conoco said it expected to close the Grane Field acquisition in the first quarter of 2001.

lead_paragraph: New Jersey residents, faced with increases in the cost of home heating oil this winter, can supplement their fuel supply by cutting wood in four state forests and one state park for $15 a cord while the supply lasts. A total of 490 cords of wood are available from selected sites in Wharton State Forest, Hammonton; Lebanon State Forest, New Lisbon, Belleplain State Forest, Woodbine; Stokes State Forest, Branchville, and High Point State Park, Sussex. Reservations for a cutting permit, issued by the Department of Environmental Protection and good for two days, must be made at the individual forests or park. Karen DeMasters

abstract: Unocal Corp will invest $500 million in Thailand next year, up from $400 million this year; company struck oil in waters off Thailand and hopes to begin pumping up to 15,000 barrels of crude oil a day from offshore field next year (S)
snippet: Unocal Corp will invest $500 million in Thailand next year, up from $400 million this year; company struck oil in waters off Thailand and hopes to begin pumping up to 15,000 barrels of crude oil a day from offshore field next year (S)
lead_paragraph: The California-based oil company Unocal said it would invest $500 million in Thailand next year, up from $400 million this year. The company recently struck oil in waters off Thailand and hopes to begin pumping up to 15,000 barrels of crude oil a day from the offshore field next year. Unocal's natural gas fields in the Gulf of Thailand already supply 30 percent of the country's power needs, according to the company, and generated 34.6 billion baht ($800 million) in revenue last year. Unocal also supplies Thailand with natural gas from a joint venture in neighboring Myanmar. Wayne Arnold

abstract: China's Sinopec Corp raises $3.5 billion in initial public offering (S)
snippet: China's Sinopec Corp raises $3.5 billion in initial public offering (S)
lead_paragraph: Brushing aside last-minute questions about its parent company's dealings, China's No. 2 oil company, Sinopec, raised $3.5 billion in an initial public offering today. Sinopec priced the offering at 1.61 Hong Kong dollars, or 21 cents, a share, and $20.65 for each American depository receipt. It is the year's second-largest Chinese stock sale after China Unicom, a cellular company, which raised $5.6 billion in June. Just before the offer, Sinopec confirmed that its parent owned a joint venture in Sudan.

lead_paragraph: China Petroleum and Chemical, or Sinopec, began the Hong Kong portion of its $3.85 billion global share sale yesterday, seeking to tempt investors with its prospect of expanding its retail gasoline sales. China's No. 1 oil refiner is offering about $192 million worth of shares to the public, a week after MTR attracted demand for 30 times the number of shares on offer. Sinopec is seeking to sell a 20 percent stake to overseas investors to raise cash to finance a corporate overhaul and to repay debt, in the third major sale of state-owned assets from China this year.

lead_paragraph: Transocean Sedco Forex Inc. said the Justice Department had asked for more information about the company's proposed $8.4 billion purchase of a rival oil driller, the R & B Falcon Corporation. The request was not expected to delay the transaction from being completed in the first quarter, the companies said. In August, Transocean agreed to buy R & B Falcon to create the world's largest fleet of offshore oil and natural gas drilling rigs. The Justice Department is studying the planned union to see how it might affect competition. Transocean shares rose $1, to $56.94, in early trading. R & B Falcon rose 63 cents, to $27.06. Both companies are based in Houston. (Bloomberg News)

snippet: Delta Petroleum Corp agrees to buy stakes in 680 wells in Texas and New Mexico from Saga Petroleum Corp for $49.5 million in cash and stock; wells produce 1,750 barrels of oil and gas a day (S)
lead_paragraph: The Delta Petroleum Corporation, an oil and natural gas exploration company based in Denver, agreed to buy stakes in 680 wells in Texas and New Mexico from the Saga Petroleum Corporation for $49.5 million in cash and stock. Delta paid $500,000 in cash and 289,583 restricted common shares as a deposit and plans to pay most of the rest by Dec. 1, the company said. Delta said it did not yet have financing needed to complete the purchase. The wells produce 1,750 barrels of oil and gas a day.

abstract: French consumer confidence falls at steepest pace in five years in September as soaring fuel prices erodes shoppers' purchasing power (S)
snippet: French consumer confidence falls at steepest pace in five years in September as soaring fuel prices erodes shoppers' purchasing power (S)
lead_paragraph: French consumer confidence fell at the steepest pace in five years in September as soaring fuel prices eroded shoppers' purchasing power. An index balancing positive and negative responses to questions about personal finances and spending fell to minus 8 from a revised record high of 2 in July, the national statistics office, Insee, said. That is the lowest level since July 1999 and the first negative reading in six months. A tripling in the cost of crude oil since early last year has been amplified throughout the 11-country euro region by a weaker currency. French consumer spending fell in August at the steepest pace in four years.

abstract: Editorial in series, Campaign 2000, on issues in presidential campaign focuses on 'pronounced' differences between Gov George W Bush and Vice Pres Al Gore on energy policy; says sharp rise in oil prices has given energy new and unexpected prominence but that what ought to be serious debate has been marred by unedifying accusations about who deserves blame for allowing US to sink further into dependence on oil and has diverted attention from inconvenient truths about America's energy problem (M)
snippet: Editorial in series, Campaign 2000, on issues in presidential campaign focuses on 'pronounced' differences between Gov George W Bush and Vice Pres Al Gore on energy policy; says sharp rise in oil prices has given energy new and unexpected prominen...
lead_paragraph: The sharp rise in oil prices over the last few months has given energy issues new and unexpected prominence in the presidential campaign. But what ought to be a serious debate has been marred by unedifying accusations about who deserves blame for allowing America to sink further into ''dependence on foreign oil.'' Gov. George W. Bush says the Democrats have inhibited oil exploration with their environmental and tax policies. Vice President Al Gore says the Republicans have allowed ''big oil'' to put profits ahead of the American consumer. All this has diverted attention from two inconvenient truths about America's energy problem.

lead_paragraph: Kaneb Pipe Line Partners L.P., a transporter of fuels refined from petroleum, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Shore Terminals L.L.C. for $160.75 million in cash and shares of the partnership to expand its West Coast terminal business. Kaneb offered $106 million in cash and two million of its partnership units, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange. The units are valued at $54.75 million, based on Monday's closing price. The acquisition will give Kaneb seven petroleum products terminals with a total capacity of 7.8 million barrels, the company said.

lead_paragraph: It's interesting watching the American oil crisis/debate from here in Tokyo. The Japanese are cool as cucumbers today -- no oil protests, no gas lines, no politicians making crazy promises. That's because Japan has been preparing for this day since the 1973 oil crisis by steadily introducing natural gas, nuclear power, high-speed mass transit and conservation, and thereby steadily reducing its dependence on foreign oil. And unlike the U.S., the Japanese never wavered from that goal by falling off the wagon and becoming addicted to S.U.V.'s -- those they just make for the Americans.

abstract: Paul Krugman's Op-Ed column on blockade by truckers protesting high fuel prices in Britain and Prime Min Tony Blair's refusal to give in to demands for tax cuts; says for time being Blair has won and he is likely to pay heavy political cost for his stand on principle; says high taxes on fuel in Britain are offset by lower general sales taxes and income taxes, and any reduction in fuel taxes would eventually have to be matched by increases in other taxes; says there are good reasons to single out fuel for higher taxes (M)
snippet: Paul Krugman's Op-Ed column on blockade by truckers protesting high fuel prices in Britain and Prime Min Tony Blair's refusal to give in to demands for tax cuts; says for time being Blair has won and he is likely to pay heavy political cost for hi...
lead_paragraph: Tony Blair showed real backbone last week. Faced with a stunningly effective blockade by truckers protesting high fuel prices, the British prime minister flatly refused to give in to demands for tax cuts. The initial result was extensive disruption -- not just closed gas stations but shortages of bread and milk in supermarkets, delays in medical procedures and in general a state of chaos all too reminiscent of the U.S. gasoline shortage of 1979. By the end of the week, however, the protests seemed to be subsiding in Britain (though similar protests were still growing elsewhere in Europe). So for the time being Mr. Blair has won -- though no good deed goes unpunished, and he is likely to pay a heavy political cost for his stand on principle.

lead_paragraph: The cost of oil is rising again, and the conventional wisdom in the industrialized countries is that prices can only come down if OPEC increases oil production. President Clinton, meeting with the Saudi crown prince, Abdullah, last week in New York, followed this line, cautioning the prince that high oil prices threaten the global economy. The finance ministers of European Union nations echoed his warnings and called on OPEC to pump more oil.

abstract: Editorial observes that high price of oil is both testament to global economic boom and threat to its continuation
snippet: Editorial observes that high price of oil is both testament to global economic boom and threat to its continuation
lead_paragraph: The high price of oil is both a testament to the current global economic boom and a threat to its continuation. The heartening news is that the oil-producing nations themselves seem to realize this, and are intent on trying to drive prices lower. Whether there is enough unused production capacity to accomplish this in the short run remains to be seen, but the political will to try is welcome.

abstract: Irish inflation rate remained at 6.2 percent in August, highest in European Union; government says rate will moderate by end of year, but Irish economists predict that worldwide increase in oil prices will push inflation up to 7 percent within next few months; three of Ireland's largest trade unions call for renegotiation of national wage agreement put in place when inflation ran at 2.5 percent (S)
snippet: Irish inflation rate remained at 6.2 percent in August, highest in European Union; government says rate will moderate by end of year, but Irish economists predict that worldwide increase in oil prices will push inflation up to 7 percent within nex...
lead_paragraph: The inflation rate in Ireland remained at 6.2 percent in August, the highest in the European Union, according to figures released by the Central Statistics Office. The government said the rate would moderate by the end of the year, but Irish economists predicted that the worldwide increase in oil prices would push inflation up to 7 percent within the next few months. In response to the figures, three of Ireland's largest trade unions called for a renegotiation of the national wage agreement put in place when inflation ran at 2.5 percent. Brian Lavery

lead_paragraph: The Precision Drilling Corporation, Canada's largest oil well driller, said it agreed to buy a rival well-service company CenAlta Energy Services Inc., for about 207.9 million Canadian dollars ($140.7 million) in stock to expand in the western part of the country. Precision Drilling will pay 0.1432 common share, or about 7.88 dollars, for each CenAlta share, the company said. CenAlta gives Precision more rigs that provide specialty services like well maintenance at a time when oil prices near 10-year highs have prompted more exploration in western Canada's oil fields.

abstract: PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd will buy oil and natural gas businesses of Montana Power Company for $475 million (S)
snippet: PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd will buy oil and natural gas businesses of Montana Power Company for $475 million (S)
lead_paragraph: PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd. agreed to buy oil and natural gas businesses of the Montana Power Company yesterday for $475 million to add fields that will increase its gas production by more than 10 percent. PanCanadian will get properties in Alberta, Montana, Colorado, Oklahoma and Wyoming, as well as three gas pipelines that link Alberta and Saskatchewan to Montana, giving access to United States markets. The fields hold reserves of 550 billion cubic feet of gas and 20 million barrels of crude oil, according to PanCanadian, which is based in Calgary, Alberta. Montana Power, based in Butte, said it planned to invest the proceeds in Touch America, its fiber optic telecommunications business. Montana Power rose 25 cents, to $34.38.

abstract: Key Production Co, an explorer and producer of oil and gas, agrees to buy a rival, Columbus Energy, for $22.7 million (S)
snippet: Key Production Co, an explorer and producer of oil and gas, agrees to buy a rival, Columbus Energy, for $22.7 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The Key Production Company, an explorer and producer of oil and gas, agreed to buy a rival, Columbus Energy, for $22.7 million. Columbus Energy shareholders will receive 0.335 share of Key Production for each Columbus Energy share held. That values Columbus Energy shares at about $5.97 each, 10 percent lower than Friday's closing price. The shares did not trade on Monday. Columbus Energy had 3.8 million shares outstanding as of July 12. Key Production will pay $22.7 million in its shares and assume $4.9 million in Columbus Energy debt, said Michael Logan, a Columbus spokesman.

abstract: Shareholders of Russian oil company Sidanko approve plan that would return assets of oil-producing subsidiary to BP Amoco, Russia's biggest foreign investor; shareholders vote to increase Sidanko's share capital by 37.7 percent, which will give rival oil company, Tyumen Oil, a stake in Sidanko and will allow BP Amoco to retain its 10 percent stake (S)
snippet: Shareholders of Russian oil company Sidanko approve plan that would return assets of oil-producing subsidiary to BP Amoco, Russia's biggest foreign investor; shareholders vote to increase Sidanko's share capital by 37.7 percent, which will give ri...
lead_paragraph: Shareholders of the Russian oil company Sidanko approved a plan that would return the assets of an oil-producing subsidiary to BP Amoco, Russia's biggest foreign investor. Shareholders voted to increase Sidanko's share capital by 37.7 percent, which will give a rival oil company, Tyumen Oil, a stake in Sidanko and will allow BP Amoco to retain its 10 percent stake. Last year, Tyumen pushed Sidanko's subsidiary into bankruptcy and bought it at a bargain price over BP Amoco's objections. Under the new agreement, Tyumen will return the assets to Sidanko in exchange for a stake of 25 percent plus one share. Sabrina Tavernise

abstract: German factory prices rise in July at their fastest annual rate in nine years, mainly because of continuing strength of oil prices (S)
snippet: German factory prices rise in July at their fastest annual rate in nine years, mainly because of continuing strength of oil prices (S)
lead_paragraph: German factory prices rose in July at their fastest annual rate in nine years, mainly because of the continuing strength of oil prices. The producer price index rose 0.7 percent from June and 3.3 percent for the year, much faster than analysts' forecasts. The annual rate was the highest since July 1991. But even excluding the rise in oil prices, producer prices rose 0.6 percent for the month and 2.8 percent for the year.

snippet: French investigators, reviewing possibility that kickbacks were paid by Elf Aquitaine for purchase of dilapidated East German oil refinery, issue arrest warrant for Dieter Holzer, suspect (S)
lead_paragraph: French investigators looking into the possibility that kickbacks were paid by the French oil company Elf Aquitaine for the purchase of a dilapidated oil refinery in the former East Germany have issued an international arrest warrant for Dieter Holzer, a businessman with links to German intelligence who is suspected of having paid millions of dollars in bribes. Mr. Holzer has admitted to receiving $23 million in ''commissions'' in the 1992 deal by Elf for a refinery in Leuna, in eastern Germany, but he denies paying any of the money as kickbacks. Elf has since been acquired by the French oil company Total.

abstract: Conoco will sell fuel on American Petroleum Exchange, Internet-based wholesale market for gasoline and diesel fuel (S)
snippet: Conoco will sell fuel on American Petroleum Exchange, Internet-based wholesale market for gasoline and diesel fuel (S)
lead_paragraph: Conoco said yesterday that it would sell fuel on the American Petroleum Exchange, an Internet-based wholesale market for gasoline and diesel fuel. The exchange, which is scheduled to open in early September, will function as a reverse auction, with customers listing their fuel needs and suppliers, like Conoco, bidding for the contracts. A Conoco spokeswoman said the company had not set aside a specific amount of fuel to sell through the exchange, noting that volume would be determined by demand. Neela Banerjee

lead_paragraph: The British-Norwegian construction and engineering company Kvaerner made a $506 million offer for the Norwegian oil-services company Aker Maritime to build its oil and gas business abroad. The new combined oil and gas unit would have annual sales of about $2.5 billion and about 21,000 employees in 40 countries, Kvaerner said. Kvaerner bid 0.79 of a share for each Aker share, or 94.8 kronor based on Friday's closing price. The bid ended weeks of speculation about the companies after Aker Maritime took a surprise 26.4 percent stake in Kvaerner.

abstract: Okioc, foreign oil consortium, discoveres oil in Caspian Sea offshore of Kazakhstan; photo (S)
snippet: Okioc, foreign oil consortium, discoveres oil in Caspian Sea offshore of Kazakhstan; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: A foreign oil consortium finally confirmed industry talk by announcing it had discovered oil in the Caspian Sea off shore from Kazakhstan, an area that has attracted much excitement in recent months. The consortium, known by its acronym, Okioc, said it had found oil in a 3.2-mile-deep well at a huge field called Kashagan. A spokesman said Okioc had not established the volume of oil in Kashagan. Earlier this month, Kazakhstan's president, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, said that Kashagan possessed 50 billion barrels of oil, a volume that would make it the world's largest offshore oil field. Steve LeVine

abstract: Editorial lauds announcement by Ford Motor Co that it will increase average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over next five years; says move deserves applause from anyone who worries about carbon dioxide's contribution to global warming (M)
snippet: Editorial lauds announcement by Ford Motor Co that it will increase average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over next five years; says move deserves applause from anyone who worries about carbon dioxide's contribution to g...
lead_paragraph: The various industries responsible for much of the country's air pollution -- the oil companies, the automakers, the big utilities -- have usually resisted federal clean air regulations, routinely overestimating the costs of the regulations while underestimating the ability of their engineers to satisfy them. In the 30 years since the passage of the Clean Air Act, industry has rarely been out in front of government. Yesterday, however, the Ford Motor Company reversed this paradigm with the announcement that it would increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years. It did so even though Congress recently rejected yet another effort by environmentalists to tighten up fuel economy standards.

headline.main: Ford's Clean Air Breakthrough

abstract: Apex Oil Co raises its bid for Crown Central Petroleum Corp to $10.50 a share in cash, topping its earlier hostile bid of $10 and competing offer of $9.50 a share from Rosemore Inc (S)
snippet: Apex Oil Co raises its bid for Crown Central Petroleum Corp to $10.50 a share in cash, topping its earlier hostile bid of $10 and competing offer of $9.50 a share from Rosemore Inc (S)
lead_paragraph: The Apex Oil Company raised its bid for the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation to $10.50 a share in cash, topping its earlier hostile bid of $10 and a competing offer of $9.50 a share for the oil refinery owner. Apex, based in St. Louis, is a privately held distributor of oil and a major shareholder of Crown Central. It said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had raised its cash offer on Friday in a meeting with a Crown Central board member, Michael Dacey. The board of Crown Central, based in Baltimore, has accepted an offer for $9.50 a share from Rosemore Inc., a company headed by the son of Crown Central's chairman and chief executive, Henry Rosenberg Jr. The Apex bid would value all of Crown Central's 10.1 million outstanding Class A and Class B shares at $105.7 million.

abstract: Brazil's state-owned oil company Petrobras could be fined up to $84 million after oil spill on July 16 polluted river in southern state of Parana; graph (S)
snippet: Brazil's state-owned oil company Petrobras could be fined up to $84 million after oil spill on July 16 polluted river in southern state of Parana; graph (S)
lead_paragraph: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, could be fined up to $84 million after an oil spill on Sunday polluted a river in the southern state of Parana. The 25,000-barrel spill came a week after the government had put about $5 billion of the company's voting shares up for sale to the Brazilian public. Investors have until the end of July to place their orders. The remaining shares will be sold to international investors. Last year, Petrobras was fined $29 million for a spill in Guanabara Bay in Rio de Janeiro. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

abstract: Meridian Resource Corp says it might buy back preferred and common stock from Royal Dutch/Shell Group for $114 million to reduce its shares outstanding (S)
snippet: Meridian Resource Corp says it might buy back preferred and common stock from Royal Dutch/Shell Group for $114 million to reduce its shares outstanding (S)
lead_paragraph: The Meridian Resource Corporation, an oil and natural-gas exploration company, said yesterday that it might buy back preferred and common stock from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group for $114 million to reduce its shares outstanding. Meridian bought an option to buy back all its preferred shares, valued at $135 million and convertible into 12.8 million common shares and 6 million additional common shares. Shell, the world's second-largest publicly traded oil company, obtained the securities in 1998 when it sold oil fields in Louisiana to Meridian. Houston-based Meridian is paying Shell a million shares, valued at $5.1 million, for the option.

abstract: New Jersey State Sen Joseph Vitale calls for measure that would allow motorists to buy gasoline over Internet by lifting 1938 ban against selling at lower-than-advertised prices (S)
snippet: New Jersey State Sen Joseph Vitale calls for measure that would allow motorists to buy gasoline over Internet by lifting 1938 ban against selling at lower-than-advertised prices (S)
lead_paragraph: State Senator Joseph F. Vitale, Democrat from Woodbridge, last week called for a measure that would allow motorists to buy gasoline over the Internet. Web sites like Priceline. com now let consumers bid what they want to pay for gas at nearby stations, but a New Jersey law dating from 1938 prohibits stations from selling at prices lower than advertised. Only four other states have similar bans, said Senator Vitale, adding that Internet sales of gasoline could save motorists as much as 20 cents a gallon. NATANIA BLUMENKEHL

abstract: Brazilians will pay about 11.3 percent more at gasoline pump beginning July 15 because of government adjustments in prices to reflect rising cost of fuel (S)
snippet: Brazilians will pay about 11.3 percent more at gasoline pump beginning July 15 because of government adjustments in prices to reflect rising cost of fuel (S)
lead_paragraph: Starting on Saturday, Brazilians will pay about 11.3 percent more at the gasoline pump because of government adjustments in prices to reflect the rising cost of fuel. At the wholesale level, the government increased gasoline and diesel prices by 15 percent, while kerosene, used as jet fuel, lost a government subsidy and jumped 34.5 percent. Butane gas, which most Brazilians use for cooking, will increase 18 percent. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

abstract: Forest Oil Corp acquires Forcenergy Inc for about $615 million in stock to add wells in Alaska and Gulf of Mexico (S)
snippet: Forest Oil Corp acquires Forcenergy Inc for about $615 million in stock to add wells in Alaska and Gulf of Mexico (S)
lead_paragraph: The Forest Oil Corporation, a natural gas and oil exploration company, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, Forcenergy Inc., for about $615 million in stock to add wells in Alaska and the Gulf of Mexico. Forest will swap 1.6 shares for each Forcenergy share, valuing Forcenergy at $25.60 a share, based on Friday's close. Forest holders will own 56 percent of the new company. The Miami-based Forcenergy emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February. Forcenergy's shares rose 93.75 cents, to $22.125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Forest, based in Denver, fell $1.875 each, or 12 percent, to $14.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

abstract: BP Amoco PLC plans to increase capital spending by 13 percent, to $13.5 billion, annually in next three years to increase oil and natural gas output and raise profit; chief executive Sir John Browne says company is ahead on its plan to cut costs, which will save $4.7 billion this year and $5.8 billion next year; photo (S)
snippet: BP Amoco PLC plans to increase capital spending by 13 percent, to $13.5 billion, annually in next three years to increase oil and natural gas output and raise profit; chief executive Sir John Browne says company is ahead on its plan to cut costs, ...
lead_paragraph: After completing $100 billion of takeovers in 19 months, BP Amoco P.L.C. plans to increase capital spending by 13 percent, to $13.5 billion, annually in the next three years to increase oil and natural gas output and raise profit. The company is ahead on its plan to cut costs, which will save $4.7 billion this year and $5.8 billion next year, the chief executive, Sir John Browne, told investors in London in an annual address. Of the $13.5 billion in spending, $8 billion will go to finding and producing oil and natural gas. BP is focusing on its most promising projects, in particular gas output from Trinidad and oil development in deep waters in the Gulf of Mexico.

snippet: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, begins country's largest public stock offering, selling 16.6 percent stake in company for about $4.4 billion; company plans to maintain 51 percent stake in Petrobras (S)
lead_paragraph: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, began the country's largest public stock offering, selling a 16.6 percent stake in the company for about $4.4 billion. Initially, shares will be sold to individual Brazilian investors and the government-managed salary- guarantee funds before they are available to domestic and international institutional investors sometime after Aug. 2. Petrobras is awaiting approval from the United Securities and Exchange Commission to sell American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange. The government plans to maintain a 51 percent stake in Petrobras. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

lead_paragraph: James Giffen, an American trade consultant under investigation by United States prosecutors, has not broken any Kazakh laws and is not under investigation in Kazakhstan, the country's general prosecutor's office said. United States prosecutors are investigating whether Mr. Giffen, a consultant to the Kazakh government, funneled millions of dollars in payments from major oil companies to Kazakh officials. In the late 1980's, Mr. Giffen, a lawyer by training, led a coalition of American companies that was set up to form joint ventures in the Soviet Union. More recently, he brokered agreements between the Kazakh government and oil companies. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The county cannot keep gasoline prices from rising, but it can help consumers find stations that tend to have the lowest prices. The county's Department of Consumer Protection has been surveying Westchester's 400 stations and is posting the information by ZIP code and municipality on the county's Web site: www.westchestergov.com. lead_paragraph: Russia's property ministry is expected to set the terms next week for the sale of an 85 percent stake in Onako, a state-controlled oil company. Its output is equal to about 10 percent of Russia's biggest oil company, Lukoil Holding, according to the United Financial Group, a brokerage firm in Moscow. The ministry also said it planned to sell a 4.5 percent stake in Lukoil on the New York Stock Exchange in August. The sales are expected to raise at least $714 million for the government. lead_paragraph: Norway, the world's second-largest oil exporter, will lift limits on its oil output starting Saturday, allowing production to increase by 3 percent. Norway will add 100,000 barrels a day to its current daily oil production of 3.2 million barrels. ''There seems to be a need for more oil in the market,'' said Olav Akselsen, Norway's oil minister. ''To allow stocks to build and avoid too tight an oil market, it is necessary to increase production.''

abstract: Editorial observes that few politicians have been able to resist exploiting public anger over $2-a-gallon gasoline in Midwest, but none have shed much light on subject
snippet: Editorial observes that few politicians have been able to resist exploiting public anger over $2-a-gallon gasoline in Midwest, but none have shed much light on subject
lead_paragraph: Few politicians have been able to resist exploiting public anger over $2-a-gallon gasoline in the Midwest. But none have shed much light on the subject. Vice President Al Gore suspects that oil companies are gouging customers, and he would not mind if voters took revenge on Gov. George W. Bush, a former oil company executive. Mr. Bush accuses the administration of having sat back while OPEC tripled the price of crude oil. He also cites Mr. Gore's book on the environment to suggest that Mr. Gore thinks gas prices are too low to begin with. Others have called for relaxing environmental standards.

abstract: Russian government will impose at least 35 percent increase on crude oil export tax on Aug 1, move to provide additional budget revenue from rising world demand and higher prices; will raise duty to 27 euros, or about $25 a metric ton, from current 20 euros; Deputy Prime Min Viktor Khristenko says if price of oil exceeds $29 a barrel on Aug 1, government will raise duty to 34 euros a metric ton--a 70 percent increase; photo (M)
snippet: Russian government will impose at least 35 percent increase on crude oil export tax on Aug 1, move to provide additional budget revenue from rising world demand and higher prices; will raise duty to 27 euros, or about $25 a metric ton, from curren...
lead_paragraph: The Russian government will impose at least a 35 percent increase on a crude oil export tax on Aug. 1, a move to provide additional budget revenue from rising world demand and higher prices. Russia will raise the duty to 27 euros, or about $25 a metric ton, from the current 20 euros, Russian news agencies quoted Deputy Prime Minister Viktor Khristenko. If the price of oil exceeds $29 a barrel on Aug. 1, the government will raise the duty to 34 euros a metric ton -- a 70 percent increase.

abstract: Canadian Occidential Petroleum Ltd says testing of well in Colombia confirms discovery of about 1.4 billion barrels of oil, at least 20 percent of which can be profitably extracted (S)
snippet: Canadian Occidential Petroleum Ltd says testing of well in Colombia confirms discovery of about 1.4 billion barrels of oil, at least 20 percent of which can be profitably extracted (S)
lead_paragraph: Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd. said testing of a well in Colombia confirmed the discovery of about 1.4 billion barrels of oil, at least 20 percent of which can be profitably extracted. Alberto Calderon, the president of Empresa Colombiana de Petroleos, the Colombian state oil company, said the find should increase the likelihood that Colombia would remain self-sufficient in oil after 2004, when its existing reserves are expected to dry up. The find of the Guando field is the biggest in Colombia after BP Amoco's Cusiana and Cupiagua fields and Occidental Petroleum's Cano Limon field, the Colombian company said.

snippet: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-Shing plans to create large publicly owned company in Canadian oil sector--Husky Energy Inc--by merging privately held Husky Oil Ltd with Renaissance Energy Ltd, both of Calgary; Husky Oil will pay equivalent of 19.40 C...
lead_paragraph: The Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-Shing plans to create a large publicly owned company in the Canadian oil sector -- Husky Energy Inc. -- by merging the privately held Husky Oil Ltd. with Renaissance Energy Ltd., both of Calgary. Husky Oil will pay the equivalent of 19.40 Canadian dollars in cash and stock for each Renaissance share, a total of 2.8 billion Canadian dollars ($1.9 billion). Shareholders of Renaissance will own 35 percent of the new company and the current owners of Husky Oil will own 65 percent. The Li family owns 49 percent of Husky Oil directly and controls the remaining 51 percent. Timothy Pritchard

abstract: Conoco Inc agrees to buy assets in British waters of North Sea of Norsk Hydro ASA for $540 million to increase output at time of rising oil and natural gas prices; purchase will increase Conoco's British oil output by 30 percent (S)
snippet: Conoco Inc agrees to buy assets in British waters of North Sea of Norsk Hydro ASA for $540 million to increase output at time of rising oil and natural gas prices; purchase will increase Conoco's British oil output by 30 percent (S)
lead_paragraph: Conoco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy assets in British waters of the North Sea of Norsk Hydro A.S.A. for $540 million to increase output at a time of rising oil and natural gas prices. The purchase will increase Conoco's British oil output by 30 percent. It also includes a stake in Britain's biggest gas field, stakes in seven other oil and gas fields, and more than 30 exploration licenses. Conoco is based in Houston. Norsk Hydro, Norway's largest publicly traded company, is selling the assets to focus on Angola and other promising deep-water exploration areas.

lead_paragraph: Gasoline prices have risen above $2 a gallon in Chicago and Milwaukee, about 25 percent higher than two months ago, angering drivers and sending political shock waves through Washington. Drivers blame retailers. Refiners blame federal regulations, the courts and OPEC. Federal regulators suspect price fixing. Some of these charges are plain wrong. Others have more merit but do not account for the whole problem.

abstract: International petroleum companies, in vote of confidence for Brazil's recently opened oil industry and potential oil resources, spend about $262 million to buy 21 onshore and offshore drilling sites (S)
snippet: International petroleum companies, in vote of confidence for Brazil's recently opened oil industry and potential oil resources, spend about $262 million to buy 21 onshore and offshore drilling sites (S)
lead_paragraph: In a vote of confidence for Brazil's recently opened oil industry and potential oil resources, petroleum companies from around the world spent about $262 million to buy 21 onshore and offshore drilling sites. Brazil's state-owned oil company Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, spent $152 million for winning bids on seven of the sites. The winners, which also include Chevron, Shell Brasil and Union Pacific, are expected to invest more than $1 billion in the next five years. Last June, the government auctioned 12 oil drilling sites for $178 million. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

abstract: Petroleo Brasileiro SA, Brazil's national petroleum agency, says it authorized 44 companies from around the world, including the Exxon Mobil Corp and Texaco Inc, to bid on 23 new oil and gas exploration blocks as part of the government's effort to diversify country's petroleum industry (S)
snippet: Petroleo Brasileiro SA, Brazil's national petroleum agency, says it authorized 44 companies from around the world, including the Exxon Mobil Corp and Texaco Inc, to bid on 23 new oil and gas exploration blocks as part of the government's effort to...
lead_paragraph: Brazil's national petroleum agency said it had authorized 44 companies from around the world, including the Exxon Mobil Corporation and Texaco Inc., to bid on 23 new oil and gas exploration blocks as part of the government's effort to diversify the country's petroleum industry. The blocks, which include 10 onshore and 13 offshore leases, will be sold at an auction on June 7. Brazil's oil and gas exploration was dominated by the state-owned oil company Petroleo Brasileiro S.A. until its monopoly ended in 1998. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

abstract: US and Mexico agree to divide 6,640-square-mile area of continental shelf in central Gulf of Mexico, believed to be rich in oil; both agree not to drill sea floor for ten years, while geology of area is studied (S)
snippet: US and Mexico agree to divide 6,640-square-mile area of continental shelf in central Gulf of Mexico, believed to be rich in oil; both agree not to drill sea floor for ten years, while geology of area is studied (S)
lead_paragraph: Mexico and the United States have agreed to divide a 6,640-square-mile area of continental shelf in the middle of the Gulf of Mexico, a region both sides believe is rich in oil. Luis Tellez, Mexico's energy minister, said at a news conference that after two years of talks, Mexico will claim 4,100 square miles, or 62 percent of the region, and the United States will take the rest. Both sides agreed not to drill for oil for 10 years while they study the geology of their segments. The treaty must be ratified by both the Mexican Senate and the United States Congress. Dan Fineren

abstract: Inland Resources Inc to buy some oil and gas assets from Flying J Inc, Bingham City, Utah, for $77.3 million in cash and stock; Inland Resources will also assume $5.8 million of debt from privately held Flyinng J (S)
snippet: Inland Resources Inc to buy some oil and gas assets from Flying J Inc, Bingham City, Utah, for $77.3 million in cash and stock; Inland Resources will also assume $5.8 million of debt from privately held Flyinng J (S)
lead_paragraph: The oil and gas producer Inland Resources Inc. agreed yesterday to buy some oil and gas assets from Flying J Inc., a rest stop chain and diesel gas seller, for $77.3 million in cash and stock. Inland Resources, based in Denver, will also assume $5.8 million of debt from the privately held Flying J. The price consists of $50 million cash and 7.8 million Inland Resources shares. The assets include nine Flying J gas stations in the Salt Lake City area and Idaho; a refinery in North Salt Lake City, Utah; and oil and gas reserves in the Uinta Basin in northeastern Utah. Flying J is based in Bingham City, Utah.

abstract: Schlumberger Ltd agrees to pay $500 million to rival, Baker Hughes Inc, for 70 percent stake in new joint venture to provide seismic services used to locate oil and gas; Schlumberger and Baker Hughes will combine their seismic divisions to form venture called Western GECO (S)
snippet: Schlumberger Ltd agrees to pay $500 million to rival, Baker Hughes Inc, for 70 percent stake in new joint venture to provide seismic services used to locate oil and gas; Schlumberger and Baker Hughes will combine their seismic divisions to form ve...
lead_paragraph: Schlumberger Ltd., the world's No. 2 oil field services company, agreed yesterday to pay $500 million to a rival, Baker Hughes Inc., for a 70 percent stake in a new joint venture to provide seismic services used to locate oil and gas. Seismic technology is used to study the physical properties of land or water in an effort to save on the expense of drilling into dry areas. Schlumberger and Baker Hughes will combine their seismic divisions to form a venture called Western GECO. The shares of Schlumberger rose $2.3125 each, to $73.3125. Baker Hughes rose $2.125, at $36.25.

abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP, number 1 seller of carbon dioxide, agrees to pay $55 million for Devon Energy Corp's stakes in Texas pipeline that ships gas and a project that injects it into oil reservoirs; oil companies use carbon dioxide to improve production from aging fields (S)
snippet: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP, number 1 seller of carbon dioxide, agrees to pay $55 million for Devon Energy Corp's stakes in Texas pipeline that ships gas and a project that injects it into oil reservoirs; oil companies use carbon dioxide to i...
lead_paragraph: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners L.P., the No. 1 United States seller of carbon dioxide, agreed yesterday to pay $55 million for the Devon Energy Corporation's stakes in a Texas pipeline that ships gas and a project that injects it into oil reservoirs. Oil companies use carbon dioxide to improve production from aging fields. Kinder Morgan will acquire 81 percent of the 150-mile Canyon Reef Carriers Pipeline and 71 percent of the Sacroc unit, both in the Permian Basin of West Texas. Kinder Morgan, based in Houston, also will get minority stakes in two Permian Basin carbon-dioxide projects operated by the Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Spirit Energy 76 unit of the Unocal Corporation.

abstract: TotalFina Elf SA to sell oil refinery, 1,700 gasoline stations and other United States assets to Alon Israel Oil Co (S)
snippet: TotalFina Elf SA to sell oil refinery, 1,700 gasoline stations and other United States assets to Alon Israel Oil Co (S)
lead_paragraph: TotalFina Elf S.A., Europe's No. 3 oil company, agreed to sell an oil refinery; 1,700 gasoline stations; and other assets in the United States to the closely held Alon Israel Oil Company in a package analysts valued at as much as $400 million. Alon, which was founded by Israel's socialist kibbutz movement, will get Total's Big Spring refinery in western Texas and stations in Texas, New Mexico, Louisiana, Arizona and Arkansas. Alon will also get 1,125 miles of pipeline, fuel storage operations, and oil and natural gas drilling licenses. The companies did not disclose financial terms. TotalFina Elf, which is based in Paris, wants to focus on its United States chemicals and global oil exploration businesses, analysts said.

lead_paragraph: Canada will sell its remaining 18 percent stake in Petro-Canada, the country's second-largest integrated oil company, and eliminate a 25 percent limit on foreign investment in the company. abstract: Texas Eastern Products Pipeline Co amends its agreement to buy Arco Pipe Line Co from BP Amoco Inc, lowering purchase price by $36.5 million, to $318.5 million; BP Amoco would retain its interest in refined petroleum products by Seaway Pipeline Co; BP was forced to sell Seaway assets as part of Federal Trade Commission's approval on April 13 of $27.1 billion acquisition of Atlantic Richfield Co (S)
snippet: Texas Eastern Products Pipeline Co amends its agreement to buy Arco Pipe Line Co from BP Amoco Inc, lowering purchase price by $36.5 million, to $318.5 million; BP Amoco would retain its interest in refined petroleum products by Seaway Pipeline Co...
lead_paragraph: The Texas Eastern Products Pipeline Company said yesterday that it amended its agreement to buy the Arco Pipe Line Company from BP Amoco L.P., lowering the purchase price by $36.5 million, to $318.5 million. Under the new pact, BP Amoco would retain its interest in the refined petroleum products pipeline of the Seaway Pipeline Company. BP Amoco was forced to sell Seaway assets as part of the Federal Trade Commission's approval on April 13 of the $27.1 billion acquisition of the Atlantic Richfield Company. Under the amended agreement, Texas Eastern would acquire Arco's interest in the Seaway crude pipeline from Freeport, Tex., to Cushing, Okla. The Seaway system was a partnership between Arco Pipe Line and a subsidiary of the Phillips Petroleum Company.

lead_paragraph: One of Russia's largest oil companies, Surgutneftegaz, announced the terms for a stock swap as part of its plans to acquire its parent company, Surgut Holding, and other units. Surgutneftegaz would issue 12.3 billion new shares, and shareholders would get 1,000 new Surgutneftegaz shares for each holding company share. The swap is also structured to increase the control management has over Surgutneftegaz. Management currently controls about 67 percent of Surgutneftegaz's shares with voting rights. After the swap, its stake is expected to exceed 70 percent. Neela Banerjee

abstract: Exxon Mobil will sell its jet turbine lubricator business to BP Amoco's Air BP Division; had agreed to sell unit to win approval of Exxon Corp-Mobil Corp merger (S)
snippet: Exxon Mobil will sell its jet turbine lubricator business to BP Amoco's Air BP Division; had agreed to sell unit to win approval of Exxon Corp-Mobil Corp merger (S)
lead_paragraph: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its jet turbine lubricator business to the Air BP Division of BP Amoco. Financial terms of the transaction, which still requires United States regulatory approval, were not disclosed. Exxon Mobil said the business includes its blending and packaging operations in Linden, N.J., as well as research equipment, raw material and the rights to several Exxon patents. Sale of the jet turbine lubricator business was part of the divestiture package agreed to by the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation to get merger approval from the Federal Trade Commission last November. Exxon Mobil will continue to make and sell Mobil jet turbine lubricating oils worldwide.

lead_paragraph: Moving a World Bank loan closer to approval, the Chevron Corporation has agreed to take a 25 percent stake in a long-delayed Exxon Mobil Corporation-led oil production and pipeline project in Africa. Participation in the $3.5 billion Doba oil fields project, which is expected to yield 1 billion barrels over as long as 30 years, would build on the company's existing West African production, Chevron said. The pipeline, which would run from Chad to Cameroon in West Africa, has encountered repeated opposition. The opponents say that government corruption would siphon off pipeline revenue meant to ease poverty in the region, and that the project lacks safeguards against pollution.

lead_paragraph: The decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase its oil production by 1.45 million barrels a day is welcome and may, over time, lead to lower American gasoline prices. The action, which Iran, an OPEC member, unexpectedly refused to take part in, restores just over a third of production cut by the cartel over the past two years. But it should not be seen as a definitive answer to the recent sharp rise in oil prices.

abstract: Sharp rise and rapid drop in oil p
snippet: Sharp rise and rapid drop in oil p
lead_paragraph: OVER A BARRELAmericans' summer vacations threatened, the press accounts claimed -- that's when the high price of oil really got scary. All winter the price had been climbing, until on March 7 it reached a 10-year high of $34 a barrel. Government experts predicted that it wouldn't come back down to the more tolerable level of $24 till March 2001. As it turned out, however, it took only a couple of weeks for prices to drop to that point. Cheaper gas prices will follow -- it usually takes about eight weeks. So go ahead and make those motel reservations from here to the Grand Canyon.

abstract: Article on changing economy in Texas, where century-old compact between ranchers and oilmen created huge wealth that built modern state; ranchers owned land, wildcatters found oil and everyone got rich together, so that, even today, estimated one million Texans get some sort of of oil or gas royalty check; oil money built universities, football stadiums, gaudy hotels and world-class art museums, but oil is nolonger king, and state is grappling with less glamorous legacy; thousands of abandoned or idle oil wells threaten to pollute underground aquifers at time when drought has made water state's most precious natural resource; ranchers and oilmen, mythic figures of modern Texas, are fighting over cleaning up mess; high-tech and health care industries now lead thriving economy, citizen groups are fighting plans to open underground gas pipeline and new generation of Houston business leaders wants sharp reductions in smog from refineries; bravado is not yet gone in harsh desert of West Texas around Midland, where thousands of oil pumps still bob up and down in summer heat; photos; map (M)

The ranchers owned the land, the wildcatters found the oil, and everyone got rich together. Oil money built universities and football stadiums, gaudy hotels and world-class art museums.

abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp sues to block sale of Atlantic Richfield Co's Alaskan oil fields to Phillips Petroleum Co (S)
snippet: Exxon Mobil Corp sues to block sale of Atlantic Richfield Co's Alaskan oil fields to Phillips Petroleum Co (S)
lead_paragraph: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, said yesterday that it had sued to block the sale of the Atlantic Richfield Company's Alaskan oil fields to the Phillips Petroleum Company. The lawsuit, filed yesterday in state court in Los Angeles, seeks a preliminary injunction that could delay the proposed $33 billion purchase of ARCO by BP Amoco. Exxon Mobil's suit is based on the company's right of first refusal to purchase certain ARCO Alaskan assets that are included in the sale to Phillips. The rights were given, Exxon Mobil says, in contracts and agreements dating to 1964. London-based BP Amoco and ARCO agreed last week to sell ARCO's Alaskan business to Phillips Petroleum for about $7 billion.

abstract: Schlumberger Ltd says it has completed spinoff of its Sedco Forex Offshore unit and its merger with Transocean Offshore Inc, in $3.61 billion transaction that creates world's largest offshore drilling company (S)
snippet: Schlumberger Ltd says it has completed spinoff of its Sedco Forex Offshore unit and its merger with Transocean Offshore Inc, in $3.61 billion transaction that creates world's largest offshore drilling company (S)
lead_paragraph: Schlumberger Ltd., a leading oil services company, said yesterday that the spinoff of its Sedco Forex Offshore unit and its merger with Transocean Offshore Inc. had been completed in a $3.61 billion transaction that creates the world's largest offshore drilling company. Schlumberger investors received one share in Sedco Forex for each share held. The shares were exchanged for 0.1936 share in the new company, Transocean Sedco Forex Inc. Schlumberger shareholders retained a 52 percent stake in the new company. Schlumberger is getting out of offshore rig rentals to concentrate on developing technology that gets more oil out of wells. The merger lets Transocean, the third-largest offshore driller, add to its fleet of deep-water rigs.

abstract: Statistics Canada reports rising energy prices pushed Canada's inflation rate to 3 percent in March, up from 2.7 percent in February, largest increase in consumer price index since May 1995; says higher prices for fuel oil and gasoline were not reflected in prices for other goods; excluding energy, inflation rate was only 1.4 percent, small drop from February (S)
snippet: Statistics Canada reports rising energy prices pushed Canada's inflation rate to 3 percent in March, up from 2.7 percent in February, largest increase in consumer price index since May 1995; says higher prices for fuel oil and gasoline were not re...
lead_paragraph: Rising energy prices pushed Canada's inflation rate to 3 percent in March, up from 2.7 percent in February, the largest increase in the consumer price index since May 1995. But Statistics Canada said higher prices for fuel oil and gasoline were not reflected in prices for other goods. Excluding energy, the inflation rate was only 1.4 percent, a small drop from February. ''Even with the economy operating at virtually full capacity, there still appears to be little cause for concern on Canada's inflation front,'' said Marc Levesque, an economist at Toronto Dominion Bank. Timothy Pritchard

abstract: Editorial notes that home heating prices in Northeast doubled and gasoline prices rose by over 30 percent after OPEC conspired to cut oil production by millions of barrels a day; proposes opening Strategic Petroleum Reserve for 'swaps' rather than sales for cash; holds that under system of swaps, company would take oil out of reserve and sell it at current prices; maintains that extra oil on market would help drive prices down; says company would return somewhat larger amount of oil to reserve
snippet: Editorial notes that home heating prices in Northeast doubled and gasoline prices rose by over 30 percent after OPEC conspired to cut oil production by millions of barrels a day; proposes opening Strategic Petroleum Reserve for 'swaps' rather than...
lead_paragraph: Home heating prices in the Northeast, the region that relies primarily on oil to heat homes, have doubled over the past year. Indeed the residents of the Northeast have suffered a double blow. First OPEC, the consortium of oil-exporting countries, conspired last spring to cut production by millions of barrels a day. As a result, crude oil prices nearly tripled by December and gasoline prices rose by over 30 percent during the past year. Then a cold wave struck last month, drawing down inventories of home heating oil and sending its price soaring. Residents are demanding relief from Congress, but it is already too late to push down heating bills before spring.

lead_paragraph: The Santa Fe Snyder Corporation, an oil and natural gas exploration company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 33 percent interest in deepwater oil fields in the Gulf of Mexico from Marathon Oil, part of the USX-Marathon Group, for $160 million. The purchase gives Santa Fe, which is based in Houston, a 49 percent working interest in the Angus-Manatee fields, which are operated by the Shell Oil Company, the United States arm of Royal Dutch/Shell Group. In addition, Santa Fe Snyder said it agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in an Indonesian exploration project from the French oil company, TotalFina S.A. Terms were not disclosed.

lead_paragraph: The ninth-largest United States oil company, the Amerada Hess Corporation, agreed to spend $555 million in an Algerian venture as part of a plan to increase output abroad. The agreement is Amerada Hess's first exploration investment in Algeria. snippet: New Jersey Institute of Technology study finds that drivers in state spend average of 34 hours a year stuck in traffic, wasting 72 gallons of gasoline each (S)
lead_paragraph: New Jersey drivers spend an average of 34 hours a year sitting still in traffic, wasting 72 gallons of gasoline each, according to a New Jersey Institute of Technology study released last week. Drivers in Somerset County are stuck on the road the most, averaging 74 hours of lost time, and Bergen drivers are second, with 62 hours. Cape May County drivers fare the best with 1.89 hours a year. KAREN DeMASTERS

And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.

abstract: Texaco Inc says it has sold producing oilfields in Gulf of Mexico and on land along coasts of Texas and Louisiana for $81.7 million to unit of investment firm EnerVest Management Partners Ltd (S)
snippet: Texaco Inc says it has sold producing oilfields in Gulf of Mexico and on land along coasts of Texas and Louisiana for $81.7 million to unit of investment firm EnerVest Management Partners Ltd (S)
lead_paragraph: Texaco Inc., the third-largest United States oil company, said today that it had sold producing fields in the Gulf of Mexico and on land along the coasts of Texas and Louisiana for $81.7 million to a unit of the investment firm EnerVest Management Partners Ltd. The fields have estimated reserves of 10.3 million barrels of oil and 43.6 billion cubic feet of gas. The EnerVest unit, EnerVest Energy L.P., will operate 90 percent of the fields. Texaco said in February that it expected to raise more than $700 million by the second quarter from sales of oil and natural gas fields that are not meeting profit goals.

abstract: Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, plans to develop new oil discovery in Caspian Sea, first to be found in Russian section of oil-rich region (S)
snippet: Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, plans to develop new oil discovery in Caspian Sea, first to be found in Russian section of oil-rich region (S)
lead_paragraph: Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil, announced plans to develop a new oil discovery in the Caspian Sea, the first to be found in the Russian section of the oil-rich region. Lukoil has already invested $200 million in an exploratory offshore well that showed a field of about 2.2 billion barrels of oil, making it equal to early large fields found in the North Sea. The new field increases Lukoil's reserves by 15 percent, furthering the company's long-term goal of gradually replacing its aging west Siberian fields. Neela Banerjee

abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp will sever ties with about 430 gasoline stations in Texas, step it agrees to take to win approval of $85.2 billion deal that created company; terms undisclosed; company will sell Mobil's 49 percent stake in more than 315 stations in Austin, Dallas and San Antonio to Tetco Inc, Mobil's partner in venture that owns the stations; 7-Eleven agrees to buy Mobil's stake in 7 Dallas-area service stations plus 3 stations in Fort Worth area; Mobil's supply contracts in Houston and Bryan-College Station, representing about 102 stations, will go to Petroleum Wholesale Inc (S)
snippet: Exxon Mobil Corp will sever ties with about 430 gasoline stations in Texas, step it agrees to take to win approval of $85.2 billion deal that created company; terms undisclosed; company will sell Mobil's 49 percent stake in more than 315 stations ...
lead_paragraph: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would sever ties with about 430 gasoline stations in Texas, a step it agreed to take to win approval of the $85.2 billion deal that created the company. Terms were not disclosed. Exxon bought Mobil in November. The company said it would sell Mobil's 49 percent stake in more than 315 stations in Austin, Dallas and San Antonio to Tetco Inc., Mobil's partner in the venture that owns the stations. 7-Eleven Inc. agreed to buy Mobil's stakes in 7 Dallas-area service stations plus 3 stations in the Fort Worth area. Mobil's supply contracts in Houston and Bryan-College Station, representing about 102 stations, will go to the closely held Petroleum Wholesale Inc.

abstract: Crown Central Petroleum Corp says its shareholder Rosemore Inc has agreed to buy rest of company for about $67 million, ending month-long bidding war with Apex Oil Co (S)
snippet: Crown Central Petroleum Corp says its shareholder Rosemore Inc has agreed to buy rest of company for about $67 million, ending month-long bidding war with Apex Oil Co (S)
lead_paragraph: The Crown Central Petroleum Corporation, an oil refiner and fuel seller, said yesterday that its shareholder Rosemore Inc. had agreed to buy the rest of the company for about $67 million, ending a month-long bidding war with the Apex Oil Company. The closely held Rosemore will pay $9.50 a share. Rosemore owns 49 percent of Crown's Class A shares and 11 percent of its Class B shares. Rosemore's president is Edward Rosenberg, son of Crown's chairman, Henry Rosenberg. The purchase values all of Crown at $95.7 million. Both companies are based in Baltimore. Crown owns two refineries in Texas and 331 gasoline stations in the Middle Atlantic and Southeast regions. Crown's Class A and Class B shares rose 25 cents each, to $8.75.

snippet: German consumer prices rose at fastest pace in five months in December, propelled by an increase in the cost of gasoline; prices climbed 0.3 percent from November and 1.2 percent from year earlier (S)
lead_paragraph: German consumer prices rose at the fastest pace in five months in December, propelled by an increase in the cost of gasoline. Prices climbed 0.3 percent from November and 1.2 percent from a year earlier, the largest annual increase since June 1998. The higher prices reinforced expectations among some economists that the European Central Bank would raise interest rates.
