abstract: Sen Gerald Cardinale to propose bill allowing self-service gas stations in New Jersey, to try to cut prices; photo (S)
snippet: Sen Gerald Cardinale to propose bill allowing self-service gas stations in New Jersey, to try to cut prices; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: To try to curb skyrocketing gas prices, State Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Republican from Cresskill, announced last week that he would propose a bill allowing patrons to pump their own gas at the state's 3,200 service stations. Opponents of the bill argue that allowing self-service stations is a short-term solution to a long-term problem. State Senator Garry J. Furnari, a Democrat from Nutley, called the bill a ''red herring'' and said the real issue is price gouging by the oil industry. Oregon is the only other state that requires full service at all gas pumps. Senator Cardinale cannot introduce his proposal until early May, when the legislature returns from a recess. WENDY GINSBERG

lead_paragraph: Russia's third-largest oil company, Surgutneftegaz, retained Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company as an adviser on how to proceed with a plan to consolidate its subsidiaries with the holding company. The plan has aroused protests from minority shareholders, who fear that a new equity issue of up to 12 billion shares and subsequent stock swap could dilute their position. Shareholders have until Thursday to authorize the new issue. The company's stock has fallen 22 percent in the last month. Neela Banerjee

abstract: BP Amoco PLC moves significantly closer to shoring up its half-billion dollar investment in Sidanko, bankrupt Russian oil company, after creditors vote to halt the company's liquidation and accept settlement that essentially calls for a restructuring of its $431 million in debts (S)
snippet: BP Amoco PLC moves significantly closer to shoring up its half-billion dollar investment in Sidanko, bankrupt Russian oil company, after creditors vote to halt the company's liquidation and accept settlement that essentially calls for a restructur...
lead_paragraph: Russia's biggest foreign investor, BP Amoco P.L.C., moved significantly closer to shoring up its half-billion dollar investment in the bankrupt oil company Sidanko, after creditors voted to halt the company's liquidation. Creditors overwhelmingly accepted an amicable settlement of the bankruptcy, which essentially calls for a restructuring of $431 million in debts. The agreement, which could be approved by a bankruptcy court Friday, is the first significant sign of progress on a compromise struck in late December by BP Amoco and a rival Russian oil concern, the Tyumen Oil Company.

abstract: Statistics Canada says rising oil prices pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to five-year high of 2.7 percent in February, up from 2.3 percent in January; excluding energy, consumer price index rose by 1.6 percent last month (S)
snippet: Statistics Canada says rising oil prices pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to five-year high of 2.7 percent in February, up from 2.3 percent in January; excluding energy, consumer price index rose by 1.6 percent last month (S)
lead_paragraph: Rising oil prices pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to a five-year high of 2.7 percent in February, up from 2.3 percent in January, Statistics Canada said. Gasoline prices were 31 percent higher than a year earlier. Excluding energy, the consumer price index rose by 1.6 percent last month, more than economists had expected after a 1.4 percent advance in January. With oil prices higher again this month, economists predict inflation for March will be close to 3 percent -- the maximum the Bank of Canada has said is acceptable. At the least, the central bank is expected to try to slow the economy by following any interest rate increases imposed by the Federal Reserve in the United States. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

snippet: Atlantic Richfield Co will sell oil pipelines, connections and storage tanks near Cushing, Pa, to eliminate obstacle to proposed $30 billion buyout by BP Amoco (S)
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Richfield Company plans to sell oil pipelines, connections and storage tanks near Cushing, Okla., to eliminate one obstacle to its proposed $30 billion buyout by BP Amoco. The Federal Trade Commission sued last week to block the merger, partly because of concerns that the Cushing operations would enable the combined company to manipulate the price of the most commonly traded oil futures contract. Arco and BP Amoco face other challenges from the F.T.C., some related to oil pumped from Alaska's North Slope. Separately, Reuters reported that Judge Susan Illston of United States District Court scheduled the last two weeks of March to hear arguments in the case.

lead_paragraph: The oil behemoth BP Amoco will acquire Burmah Castrol for 3 billion [pounds], or $4.7 billion, taking control of the world's best-selling motor oil, Castrol. BP Amoco is paying a 74 percent premium for Burmah Castrol, valuing each share at 16.75 [pounds]. The head of BP Amoco's new global lubricants division, David Baldry, said the takeover would result in 1,700 job cuts. BP Amoco also expects to dispose of Burmah's speciality chemicals businesses.

lead_paragraph: Germany expects inflation to climb to 1 percent to 1.5 percent this year as the nation's growth accelerates to around 2.5 percent, the Finance Minister, Hans Eichel, said. As a result, there will be a clear gap between Germany's inflation rate and the 2 percent annual ceiling set by the European central bank, Mr. Eichel said. The comments come as a report showed prices of goods imported into Germany last month rose at the fastest pace in almost a decade, suggesting that rising oil costs and the euro's slide are increasing inflation.

abstract: It may be a rough summer for vacationers in their campers and sport utility vehicles. Oil prices shot up to more than $32 a barrel, amid growing fear that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might decide not to lift production when ministers meet this week in Vienna. OPEC has already discarded an informal agreement to automatically raise production by 500,000 barrels a day if the 20-day average price climbed above $28. American motorists are already paying the highest gasoline prices in a decade; in the Midwest, some gas is selling for more than $2 a gallon.   EDMUND L. ANDREWS

abstract: El Paso Energy Corp acquires oil pipeline in Southwest from Plains All American Pipeline LP for $129 million; El Paso Natural Gas Co is to acquire 1,088-mile-portion that runs from McCamey, Tex, to Bakersfield, Calif; El Paso is to spend $75 million to convert oil pipeline to natural gas pipeline (S)
snippet: El Paso Energy Corp acquires oil pipeline in Southwest from Plains All American Pipeline LP for $129 million; El Paso Natural Gas Co is to acquire 1,088-mile-portion that runs from McCamey, Tex, to Bakersfield, Calif; El Paso is to spend $75 milli...
lead_paragraph: The El Paso Energy Corporation, a fast-growing natural gas company based in Houston, agreed yesterday to buy part of an oil pipeline in the Southwest from Plains All American Pipeline L.P. for $129 million. Under the agreement, El Paso's El Paso Natural Gas Company is to acquire a 1,088-mile portion that runs from McCamey, Tex., to near Bakersfield, Calif. El Paso is to spend $75 million to convert the oil pipeline to a natural gas pipeline. The project would enable El Paso to replace its existing natural gas compression operations, reducing costs. Plains All American Pipeline, an oil transportation and storage partnership, is controlled by Plains Resources Inc. of Houston.

abstract: After one of its most raucous meetings in years, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to pump a modest additional amount of oil, a move that should at least slow the recent surge in oil and gasoline prices. But Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest producer by far, ultimately forced it and all the other countries to raise their official quotas by 1.7 million barrels a day.

abstract: Report for Canadian government by John Harker, Canadian diplomat, into activities of Talisman Energy Inc in Sudan, country which has been devastated by civil war, is critical of company's role in providing indirect support to government forces; Canada will not impose any sanctions against Talisman or against Sudan (S)
snippet: Report for Canadian government by John Harker, Canadian diplomat, into activities of Talisman Energy Inc in Sudan, country which has been devastated by civil war, is critical of company's role in providing indirect support to government forces; Ca...
lead_paragraph: A report for the Canadian government into the activities of Talisman Energy Inc. in Sudan, which has been devastated by civil war, is critical of the company's role in providing indirect support to government forces. Canada will not, however, impose any sanctions against Talisman or against Sudan. Shares of Talisman, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, rose 10 percent on the news, to $26.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange. John Harker, the Canadian diplomat who wrote the report, said that the company ''does seem to want to do what is right,'' but that it had turned a blind eye to atrocities and had allowed the military of Sudan to use airstrips at Talisman oil drilling sites.

lead_paragraph: MOST financial writers, groping for historic precedents to explain the dot-com boom, cite foreign events, like the tulip mania and the South Sea Bubble. But the most important precursors are those episodes in American history that exemplify our passion for seeking fortune and adventure in new territory. Mining and drilling, in particular, have set a mood that has never disappeared from the West. It is the attitude of extractive industry -- get in, get rich, get out.

lead_paragraph: Everybody knows that the economic crises of the 21st century will be high-tech, high-concept affairs: our networks will be disrupted by hackers or our markets will be trampled by the electronic herd. Nobody thinks that the new economy is vulnerable to mundane, old-economy crises like those of the 1970's. Gasoline lines, a world held for ransom by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries -- those scenes are as dated as bell-bottoms and disco.

abstract: With violence raging in the Middle East and lofty oil prices drawing harsh criticism of petroleum companies, it might seem an inopportune time for Chevron and Texaco to announce a merger that opens them to the scrutiny of the federal government and the jittery stock market.     But the timing has less to do with the high price of oil over the last several months and more to do with the trend toward larger oil concerns that has radically reshaped the industry in the last two years. In fact, the two companies tried to merge more than a year ago but were unable to work out the terms.

snippet: Rosemore Inc offers to buy all outstanding common shares of Crown Central Petroleum Corp in deal valued at about $83 million; Crown is weighing merger proposal by Apex Oil Co (S)
lead_paragraph: Rosemore Inc. has offered to buy all the outstanding common shares of the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation at $8.35 apiece in cash. Rosemore already holds about 49 percent of Crown's Class A stock and 11 percent of Class B stock. The offer values the oil refiner and gasoline retailer at around $83 million. Rosemore's buyout offer comes as Baltimore-based Crown weighs a merger proposal by the Apex Oil Company. Crown's Class A shares rose 62.5 cents, to $7.75, on the American Stock Exchange. The Class B shares rose 50 cents, to $7.875.

lead_paragraph: THE price of oil is affecting travel everywhere. Surcharges of $20 on a round trip are being added to most airline tickets. Airport shuttle prices are inching up. And although a spokesman for Greyhound Lines says increases in the cost of driving improve the company's business, Greyhound has also added a fuel surcharge. Officials in the hotel industry, noting the possibility that higher prices will bring a downturn in travel, say there could be an impact there, too: inexpensive motels might lower prices.

abstract: The Chevron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Texaco Inc. for about $36 billion in stock, creating the world's fourth-largest oil concern.    The companies' boards approved the deal, which is expected to be announced today, senior executives involved in the talks said. The acquisition comes during a period of high oil and gas prices and much political jostling, both in the United States and abroad, to keep those prices in check. The acquisition will probably receive intense scrutiny from regulators, who could force the combined company to divest itself of some assets, especially in states like California, where the company would dominate the retail gas station business.
lead_paragraph: The Chevron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Texaco Inc. for about $36 billion in stock, creating the world's fourth-largest oil concern.

abstract: Senators and governors from the West Coast and Alaska, as well as oil executives and lawyers, have been flocking to the Federal Trade Commission in recent weeks in what has quickly turned into one of the most contentious political and regulatory campaigns of the season.    Even as the F.T.C. approved the largest industrial merger in history a few weeks ago -- Exxon's $81 billion acquisition of Mobil -- the agency's staff recommended that a second large oil merger be blocked. Negotiations ensued among the Government and the two companies involved, BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield. But the gap over the proposed $29 billion deal remains wide, with the companies and government officials unable to agree on what impact the merger would have on gasoline prices on the West Coast, the primary recipient of crude oil from Alaska's North Slope.
lead_paragraph: Senators and governors from the West Coast and Alaska, as well as oil executives and lawyers, have been flocking to the Federal Trade Commission in recent weeks in what has quickly turned into one of the most contentious political and regulatory campaigns of the season.

But energy stocks, led by Exxon Mobil, rose as oil prices bolted to their highest level since the 1990-91 Persian Gulf crisis.

lead_paragraph: Much of next week the Hudson and New York Harbor will be filled with tall ships, sailboats and other craft for OpSail 2000. The festivities will be overseen by the United States Coast Guard. One of the Coast Guard units on the scene will be the Atlantic Strike Team, which responds to environmental emergencies. The team is based at Fort Dix and consists of 38 men and women on active duty and 50 reserve. The commander is Gail Kulisch, a former Coast Guard ship commander, executive officer, navigator and marine environmental response officer. Commander Kulisch, who assumed her post June 9, talked recently about her team's work.

abstract: Special report Secrets of History: The CIA in Iran; focuses on newly surfaced copy of Central Intelligence Agency's still classified history of 1953 coup, which reveals inner workings of CIA plot that replaced elected government with shah and set stage for 1979 Islamic revolution and generation of anti-Americanism; report discloses key role British intelligence officials played in initiating and planning coup against Prime Min Mohammed Mossadegh and shows Britain and US shared interest in maintaining West's control over Iranian oil; report, written by Dr Donald N Wilber, CIA's chief coup planner, shows operation's success was mostly matter of chance; shows agency's contempt for Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, whom it derided as coward, and describes for first time agency's tortured efforts to win his participation; operation was blueprint for later CIA plots to foment coups and destabilize governments during cold war; chronology of events; photo (L)
snippet: Special report Secrets of History: The CIA in Iran; focuses on newly surfaced copy of Central Intelligence Agency's still classified history of 1953 coup, which reveals inner workings of CIA plot that replaced elected government with shah and set ...
lead_paragraph: For nearly five decades, America's role in the military coup that ousted Iran's elected prime minister and returned the shah to power has been lost to history, the subject of fierce debate in Iran and stony silence in the United States. One by one, participants have retired or died without revealing key details, and the Central Intelligence Agency said a number of records of the operation -- its first successful overthrow of a foreign government -- had been destroyed.

abstract: Aetna Agrees to Sell Units To ING for $5 Billion in Cash  Aetna agreed to sell its international and financial services units to the ING Group of the Netherlands for $5 billion in cash, people close to the deal said.    Under the deal, which was to be announced before the opening of the stock markets in Europe today, Aetna will create a new health care company that will keep the name Aetna. ING will also assume $2.7 billion of Aetna's long-term debt. [Page C2.]    Giveaway Music Pays Off for Some  As the recording industry and commercial artists try to stamp out the distribution of copyrighted music for free in the form of computer files, tens of thousands of aspiring rock stars are happily using the technology to give their music away -- and more than a few are beginning to see some payoff. [A1.]

snippet: The surge in oil prices has created something of a dilemma for the world's big oil companies. On the one hand, the 50 percent rise in crude prices to more than dollars 30 a barrel this year has generated record profits at the major integrated oil ...
lead_paragraph: The surge in oil prices has created something of a dilemma for the world's big oil companies. On the one hand, the 50 percent rise in crude prices to more than dollars 30 a barrel this year has generated record profits at the major integrated oil companies. In recent weeks, the majors have reported earnings gains in the latest quarter ranging from 80 percent at Royal Dutch/Shell Group to more than 160 percent at Chevron Corp. and TotalFinaElf SA.

abstract: "It is ultimately the case that with any invention automobiles, televisions, radio — the benefits of those innovations show up in the economy as a range of services that people have, and it is rare to find nongovernment franchise monopolies tha
snippet: "It is ultimately the case that with any invention automobiles, televisions, radio — the benefits of those innovations show up in the economy as a range of services that people have, and it is rare to find nongovernment franchise monopolies tha
lead_paragraph: "It is ultimately the case that with any invention automobiles, televisions, radio — the benefits of those innovations show up in the economy as a range of services that people have, and it is rare to find nongovernment franchise monopolies that ever earn on a sustained basis super returns. Certainly the manufacturing sector earns returns on innovation, but to be a maker of airplanes or cars or televisions, certainly now, is not a particularly profitable return on investment.

abstract: Editorial hails Carol Browner, administrator of Environmental Protection Agency, for subjecting diesel-powered vehicles to new rules intended to reduce emissions of soot and smog-producing pollutants by 90 percent over time; says that Pres-elect George W Bush could order his new EPA administrator, Gov Christine Todd Whitman, to overturn new regulation, but that that would demonstrate amazing indifference to public's demonstrated desire for cleaner air
snippet: Editorial hails Carol Browner, administrator of Environmental Protection Agency, for subjecting diesel-powered vehicles to new rules intended to reduce emissions of soot and smog-producing pollutants by 90 percent over time; says that Pres-elect G...
lead_paragraph: Carol Browner, who has made air pollution her signature issue during eight years as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is ending her tenure with a ruling that will make the air in cities like New York much cleaner and healthier than it is today. Under a timetable announced last week by Ms. Browner and approved by President Clinton, big diesel-powered vehicles like trucks and buses will be subject to new rules that are intended to reduce emissions of soot and smog-producing pollutants by 90 percent over time. Environmentalists described the plan as the biggest step forward for cleaner air since the removal of lead from gasoline in the 1970's.

There were reports of Islamic groups claiming responsibility, but they could not be verified and American officials said their investigation had yielded no firm leads. lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE A. BOSSIDY had sworn that he would raise annual revenue at AlliedSignal to $20 billion by the time he retired as chairman and chief executive last April. His determination had even become a company slogan: ''20 in 20,'' his people would say, lopping off zeros. But as his retirement approached, revenue was still $5 billion short of the goal. So last year, Mr. Bossidy acquired Honeywell Inc., creating a company with Honeywell's name and $24 billion in revenue.

abstract: Sierra Club executive director Carl Pope letter, responding to T H Watkins's Feb 9 Op-Ed article, holds Watkins caught Sierra Club advertisement about how George W Bush ignores Texas's pollution but evidently missed Club's Arizona television campaign highlighting Sen John McCain's opposition to protecting public lands; holds while Sierra Club disagees with McCain on public lands, it agrees with him on need to get big money out of politics; notes Bush's cozy relationship with oil and utility companies that back him handsomely; adds unfornately, McCain has also bowed to special interests
